What is a VPN?

A VPN, or Virtual Private Network, is a technology that allows you to connect directly to a remote server. This connection takes place via an encrypted tunnel that protects your Personal Identifiable Information (PII). Most commercial VPNs provide additional protection by concealing your IP address behind an anonymous, untraceable address. The best VPNs not only keep your online browsing hidden from hackers but from government surveillance as well.


The key to online privacy is making sure you’re keeping as much data about your browsing activity under wraps. First, you want your IP address – your device’s unique identifier on the worldwide web – to stay hidden. Second, you want the data you send to the internet to remain secret.

Those two things are exactly what virtual private networks, more commonly known as VPNs, do. They hide your IP address behind a VPN server and encrypt your online traffic.

Most VPNs, however, are not free. When it comes to choosing which to buy, you should choose one that fits your exact needs. There are VPNs good for day-to-day use, travels, gaming, streaming, and so on. We know, choosing the perfect VPN is not easy. That’s where we come in. We’ve tested dozens of VPNs, and using a methodology we developed, we rated and ranked them to help you narrow down your options. No matter what type of VPN you’re looking for, there’s going to be a good option for you in this list. Let’s take a closer look.

Best VPN for China

China’s government blocks most foreign VPNs outright, but ExpressVPN works flawlessly on the mainland. You don’t even have to tweak any settings or activate a stealth mode, and there’s a separate version of the site that’s still accessible in China (though you’ll have to ask the support staff for the URL before you arrive).
